summary: This document is an email chain from June 18, 2020, discussing the status of a Mutual Legal Assistance Treaty (MLAT) request from the U.S. to the United Kingdom concerning a material witness, referred to as 'PA'. The emails detail a dispute between U.S. prosecutors and the UK Home Office/UK Central Authority (UKCA) over whether to proceed with the formal MLAT request or first exhaust voluntary cooperation avenues with the witness's legal team, Blackfords. The U.S. side argues voluntary efforts have failed due to a breakdown in trust and urges the UK to proceed with the MLAT.

persons.name: Dawn Browne
persons.context: UKCA official who communicated the Home Office's position requiring exhaustion of voluntary cooperation avenues before processing the MLAT request and discussed potential judicial review litigation.

persons.name: Philomena Creffield
persons.role: Deputy Director & Head of UK Central Authority, Home Office
persons.context: Senior UK official involved in the MLAT request correspondence, acknowledging the need to settle the position on the 'second investigation' (likely referring to Nygard).

persons.name: Julian Gibbs
persons.context: UKCA official copied on the email chain regarding the Material Witness PA MLAT request.

persons.name: Gary Bloxsome
persons.context: Attorney from the law firm Blackfords representing the material witness 'PA'. Correspondence indicates he stated his client was willing to assist but without concrete commitments, leading to a breakdown in trust with the U.S. prosecution team.

persons.name: Amanda J. Chadwick
persons.role: U.S. Department of Justice Attaché, U.S. Embassy - London
persons.context: U.S. DOJ Attaché in London who authored the main email arguing that voluntary interview efforts are exhausted and urging the UKCA to proceed with the MLAT request. She is the primary U.S. correspondent.

persons.name: Andrew
persons.context: Referred to in the context of the 'Nygard' investigation. The UK Home Office sought more specifics about 'Andrew's knowledge of or involvement in criminal conduct' to predicate the MLAT request on that aspect.

connections.description: Gary Bloxsome, of Blackfords law firm, is the attorney representing the material witness referred to as 'PA', who is strongly implied to be Prince Andrew.
U.S. DOJ Attaché and UKCA official engaged in diplomatic/legal discussions regarding the processing of the MLAT request and the dispute over voluntary cooperation.
The email describes a 'significant mutual lack of trust' between the U.S. case team and the witness's law firm, Blackfords, regarding arranging a voluntary interview.

events.title: UK Home Office resists MLAT request for witness 'PA'
events.description: The UK Home Office/UKCA informs U.S. officials they are hesitant to process the MLAT request for interviewing material witness 'PA' (Prince Andrew) unless the U.S. exhausts all avenues for voluntary cooperation, fearing judicial review litigation from the witness's attorneys.

events.title: Failed voluntary interview negotiations
events.description: Correspondence between the U.S. prosecution team and Gary Bloxsome of Blackfords law firm from January to June 2020 fails to secure a voluntary interview with witness 'PA', resulting in a breakdown of trust.

events.title: Blackfords states assistance is futile
events.description: Blackfords law firm sends written correspondence stating 'there is no purpose to be served in continuing to try to assist further,' which the U.S. side cites as evidence that voluntary efforts are exhausted.

events.title: U.S. requests UK proceed with MLAT on Epstein only
events.description: A U.S. official suggests withdrawing the Nygard-related aspect of the MLAT request due to lack of UK-perceived predication and asking the UK to proceed solely on the Epstein aspect.

keyFacts: The material witness referred to as 'PA' is strongly implied to be Prince Andrew, based on the context of the Epstein investigation and the involvement of his reported attorneys, Blackfords.
The UK Home Office resisted the U.S. MLAT request to interview Prince Andrew, insisting on exhausting voluntary cooperation first to avoid potential judicial review litigation from his lawyers.

The U.S. prosecution team argued that a 'significant mutual lack of trust' with Prince Andrew's lawyers (Blackfords/Gary Bloxsome) made a voluntary interview impossible, and formal MLAT procedures were necessary.
A separate aspect of the MLAT request related to 'Nygard' was challenged by the UK due to perceived lack of predication regarding 'Andrew's knowledge of or involvement'.
The email reveals high-level diplomatic tensions, with mentions of the U.S. Attorney General and UK Home Secretary potentially meeting in person over the matter.
